p: Age of breeding birds ranged between 8.4 years (1984) and 14.9 years (1990, mean: 12 ± 1.4 years, Fig. 3). Between 1990 and 2015 the average age of returning breeders showed a slightly decreasing trend from around 14 to 11 years (Pearson correlation ρ = − 0.307, t 24 = − 1.5781, p = 0.13). At the same time, average age of new breeders dropped significantly from more than 10 years in the 1990s to only 4 years in 2015 ( ρ = − 0.796, t 24 = − 1.5781, p < 0.001). The average age of new breeders increased steeply after both the 1989 and 2001 adult die-offs ( Fig. 3) indicating a substantial pool of older non-breeders ready to recruit following the disappearance of established breeders. No such spike is apparent after the 2012 die-off suggesting that the pool of older recruits has dried up over the last decade.
